main_text:
In the United States, philosophy typically makes its formal entry into
the curriculum at the college level. A growing number of high schools
offer some introduction to philosophy, often in special literature
courses for college bound students. In Europe and many other
countries, it is much more common to find philosophy in the high
school curriculum. However, philosophy prior to high school seems
relatively uncommon around the world. This may suggest that serious
philosophical thinking is not for pre-adolescents. At least three
reasons might be offered for accepting this view. First, philosophical
thinking requires a level of cognitive development that, one may
believe, is beyond the reach of most pre-adolescents. Second,
especially in the United States, the school curriculum is already
crowded; and introducing a subject like philosophy, it may be thought,
will distract students from what they need to learn. Third, given that
philosophical inquiry raises questions that more often than not resist
definitive answers, it may encourage students to become skeptics
rather than learners. However, as shall be seen, these reasons can be
challenged.
